text: But none of these things move me, neither do I count my life dear unto myself, only that I might finish my course with joy and the ministry, which I have received of the Lord Jesus, to testify the gospel of the grace of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, behold, I know that ye all, among whom I have gone preaching the kingdom of God, shall see my face no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I take you to record this day that I am pure from the blood of everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I have not refrained from declaring unto you the full counsel of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take heed therefore unto yourselves and to all the flock, in which the Holy Spirit has placed you as bishops to feed the congregation {Gr. ekklesia – called out ones} of God, which he has purchased with his own blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I know this, that after my departing, grievous wolves shall enter in among you, not sparing the flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also from among your own selves, men shall arise, speaking perverse things to draw away disciples after themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore watch and remember that by the space of three years I ceased not to warn every one night and day with tears.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, brethren, I commend you to God and to the word of his grace, which is powerful to build you up and to give you an inheritance among all those who are sanctified.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have coveted no one’s silver or gold or apparel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, ye yourselves know that these hands have ministered unto my necessities and to those that were with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have showed you in all things how that so labouring, ye ought to support the weak and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus, how he said, It is more blessed to give than to receive.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he had thus spoken, he knelt down and prayed with them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they all wept sore and fell on Paul’s neck and kissed him,
speaker: Narrator

text: sorrowing most of all for the word which he spoke, that they should see his face no more. And they accompanied him unto the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it came to pass that after we had left them and had launched, we came with a straight course unto Coos, and the day following unto Rhodes, and from there unto Patara;
speaker: Narrator

text: and finding a ship sailing over unto Phenicia, we went aboard and set forth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when we had sighted Cyprus, we left it on the left hand and sailed into Syria and landed at Tyre, for there the ship was to unload her cargo.
speaker: Narrator

text: And finding the disciples, we tarried there seven days, who said to Paul through the Spirit that he should not go up to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we had accomplished those days, we departed; and they all brought us on our way, with wives and children, until we were out of the city; and we knelt down on the shore and prayed.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we had taken our leave one of another, we embarked on the ship, and they returned home again.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we had finished our course from Tyre, we came to Ptolemais and saluted the brethren and abode with them one day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the next day Paul and those of us that were with him departed and came unto Caesarea; and we entered into the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the seven, and abode with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he had four daughters, virgins, who prophesied.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as we tarried there many days, there came down from Judaea a certain prophet, named Agabus.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he was come unto us, he took Paul’s girdle and bound his own hands and feet and said, Thus saith the Holy Spirit, So shall the Jews at Jerusalem bind the man that owns this girdle and shall deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we heard these things, both we and those of that place besought him not to go up to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul answered, What mean ye to weep and to break my heart? For I am ready not only to be bound, but also to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he would not be persuaded, we ceased, saying, Let the will of the Lord be done.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after those days we packed our baggage and went up to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: There went with us also certain of the disciples of Caesarea and brought with them one Mnason of Cyprus, an old disciple, with whom we should lodge.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we arrived at Jerusalem, the brethren received us gladly.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the day following, Paul went in with us to see James, and all the elders were gathered.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he had saluted them, he declared particularly what things God had wrought among the Gentiles by his ministry.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they heard it, they glorified the Lord and said unto him, Thou seest, brother, how many thousands of Jews there are who have believed, and they are all zealous of the law;
speaker: Narrator

text: and they are informed of thee that thou teachest all the Jews who are among the Gentiles to forsake Moses, saying that they ought not to circumcise their children, neither to walk after the customs.
speaker: Narrator

text: What is it therefore? The multitude must needs come together, for they will hear that thou art come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do therefore this that we say to thee: We have four men among us who have a vow on them;
speaker: Narrator

text: them take, and purify thyself with them, and pay their expenses, that they may shave their heads, and all may know that those things, of which they were informed concerning thee, are nothing, but that thou thyself dost also walk orderly and keep the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: As touching the Gentiles who believe, we have written and concluded that they observe no such thing, except only that they keep themselves from things offered to idols and from blood and from that which has been strangled and from fornication.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul took the men and the next day, purifying himself with them, entered into the temple to signify the accomplishment of the days of purification until an offering should be offered for each one of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the seven days were almost ended, the Jews, who were of Asia, when they saw him in the temple, stirred up all the people and laid hands on him,
speaker: Narrator

text: crying out, Men of Israel, help; this is the man that teaches everyone everywhere against the people and the law and this place and further brought Greeks also into the temple and has polluted this holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: (For before this they had seen Trophimus, an Ephesian, with him in the city, whom they supposed that Paul had brought into the temple.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So that all the city was moved, and the people ran together; and they took Paul and drew him out of the temple, and immediately the doors were shut.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as they went about to kill him, tidings came unto the tribunal of the company that all Jerusalem was in an uproar
speaker: Narrator

text: who immediately took soldiers and centurions and ran down unto them; and when they saw the tribunal and the soldiers, they left off beating Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the tribunal came near and took him and commanded him to be bound with two chains and demanded to know who he was and what he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: And some cried one thing, some another, among the multitude; and when he could not know the certainty for the tumult, he commanded him to be carried into the fortress.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he came upon the stairs, so it was that he was borne of the soldiers because of the violence of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the multitude of the people followed after, crying, Away with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as Paul was to be led into the fortress, he said unto the tribunal, May I speak unto thee? Who said, Canst thou speak Greek?
speaker: Narrator

text: Art not thou that Egyptian, who before these days made an uproar and led four thousand men out into the wilderness that were murderers?
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul said, I am certainly a Jew, a citizen of Tarsus, a city known in Cilicia; and, I beseech thee, suffer me to speak unto the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he had given him license, Paul stood on the stairs and beckoned with the hand unto the people. And when there was made a great silence, he spoke unto them in the Hebrew tongue, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: Men, brethren, and fathers, hear ye my defense which I make now unto you.
speaker: Narrator

text: (And when they heard that he spoke in the Hebrew tongue to them, they kept the more silence, and he said,)
speaker: Narrator

text: I am indeed a Jew, born in Tarsus, a city in Cilicia, yet brought up in this city at the feet of Gamaliel and taught according to the truth of the law of the fathers, zealous toward God, as ye all are this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I persecuted this way unto the death, binding and delivering into prisons both men and women.
speaker: Narrator

text: As also the prince of the priests bears me witness, and all the estate of the elders, from whom also I received letters unto the brethren, and went to Damascus to bring those who were bound there unto Jerusalem to be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it came to pass that, as I made my journey and was come near unto Damascus about noon, suddenly there shone from heaven a great light round about me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I fell unto the ground and heard a voice saying unto me, Saul, Saul, why dost thou persecute me?
speaker: Narrator

text: And I answered, Who art thou, Lord? And he said unto me, I Am Jesus of Nazareth, whom thou dost persecute.
speaker: Narrator

text: And those that were with me saw indeed the light and were afraid, but they did not hear the voice of him that spoke to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said, What shall I do, Lord? And the Lord said unto me, Arise and go into Damascus, and there it shall be told thee of all things which are appointed for thee to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when I could not see for the clarity of that light, being led by the hand of those that were with me, I came into Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: And one Ananias, a devout man according to the law, having a good witness of all the Jews who dwelt there,
speaker: Narrator

text: came unto me and stood and said unto me, Brother Saul, receive thy sight. And the same hour I looked up upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, The God of our fathers has chosen thee that thou should know his will and see that Just One and should hear the voice of his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For thou shalt be his witness unto all men of what thou hast seen and heard.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now why tarriest thou? Arise and be baptized and wash away thy sins, calling on the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it came to pass that, when I was come again to Jerusalem, even while I prayed in the temple, I was in a rapture of understanding
speaker: Narrator

text: and saw him saying unto me, Make haste and go quickly out of Jerusalem, for they will not receive thy testimony concerning me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said, Lord, they know that I imprisoned and in every synagogue beat those that believed on thee;
speaker: Narrator

text: and when the blood of thy martyr Stephen was shed, I also was standing by and consenting unto his death and kept the raiment of those that slew him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said unto me, Depart, for I will send thee far from here unto the Gentiles.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they gave him audience unto this word and then lifted up their voices and said, Away with such a fellow from the earth, for it is not fit that he should live.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as they cried out and cast off their clothes and threw dust into the air,
speaker: Narrator

text: the tribunal commanded him to be brought into the fortress and bade that he should be examined by scourging that he might know why they cried out so against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as they bound him with thongs, Paul said unto the centurion that stood by, Is it lawful for you to scourge a man that is a Roman and uncondemned?
speaker: Narrator

text: When the centurion heard that, he went and told the tribunal, saying, Take heed what thou doest, for this man is a Roman.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the tribunal came and said unto him, Tell me, art thou a Roman? He said, Yes.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the tribunal answered, With a great sum I obtained this freedom. And Paul said, But I was free born.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then straightway those who should have tormented him departed from him, and the tribunal was also afraid, after he knew that he was a Roman and because he had bound him.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day, because he wanted to know of certainty the cause for which he was accused of the Jews, he loosed him from his bands and commanded the princes of the priests and all their council to appear and brought Paul down and set him before them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul, earnestly beholding the council, said, Men and brethren, I have lived in all good conscience before God until this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the prince of the priests, Ananias, commanded those that stood by him to smite him on the mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul said unto him, God shall smite thee, thou whitewashed wall, for dost thou sit to judge me after the law and command me to be smitten contrary to the law?
speaker: Narrator

text: And those that stood by said, Dost thou revile God’s high priest?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul said, I did not know, brethren, that he was the prince of the priests, for it is written, Thou shalt not speak evil of the ruler of thy people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Paul perceived that the one part were Sadducees and the other Pharisees, he cried out in the council, Men and brethren, I am a Pharisee, the son of a Pharisee, and of the hope and resurrection of the dead I am called in question.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he had so said, there arose a dissension between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the multitude was divided.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, neither angel, nor spirit; but the Pharisees confess both.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there arose a great cry; and the scribes that were of the Pharisees’ part arose and strove, saying, We find no evil in this man, but if a spirit or an angel has spoken to him, let us not fight against God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when there arose a great dissension, the tribunal, fearing lest Paul should have been pulled in pieces by them, commanded the soldiers to go down and to take him by force from among them and to bring him into the fortress.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the night following the Lord stood by him and said, Be of good cheer, Paul, for as thou hast testified of me in Jerusalem, so must thou also bear witness at Rome.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when it was day, certain of the Jews banded together and they vowed under a curse, saying that they would neither eat nor drink until they had killed Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they were more than forty who had made this conspiracy.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they came to the princes of the priests and the elders and said, We have made a vow of anathema that we will eat nothing until we have slain Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore ye with the council signify to the tribunal that he bring him down unto you tomorrow, as though ye would enquire something more certain concerning him, and we, before he arrives, are ready to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when Paul’s sister’s son heard of their ambush, he went and entered into the fortress and told Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul called one of the centurions unto him and said, Bring this young man unto the tribunal, for he has a certain thing to tell him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took him and brought him to the tribunal and said, Paul the prisoner called me unto him and asked me to bring this young man unto thee, who has something to say unto thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the tribunal took him by the hand and went with him aside privately and asked him, What is that thou hast to tell me?
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, The Jews have agreed to ask thee that thou would bring down Paul tomorrow into the council, as though they would enquire something more certain of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do not believe them, for more than forty of them lie in wait to ambush him, who have vowed under a curse that they will neither eat nor drink until they have killed him, and now they are ready, looking for a promise from thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the tribunal then let the young man depart and charged him, See thou tell no one that thou hast showed these things to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he called unto him two centurions, saying, Make ready two hundred soldiers to go to Caesarea and seventy horsemen and two hundred spearmen, at the third hour of the night
speaker: Narrator

text: and provide them beasts that they may set Paul on and bring him safe unto Felix the governor.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he wrote a letter after this manner:
speaker: Narrator

text: Claudius Lysias unto the most excellent governor Felix sends greeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: This man was taken of the Jews and should have been killed by them; then I came with an army and rescued him, having understood that he was a Roman.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when I desired to know the cause of why they accused him, I brought him forth into their council,
speaker: Narrator

text: whom I found to be accused of questions of their law, but to have nothing laid to his charge worthy of death or of bonds.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when it was told me how the Jews lay in wait to ambush the man, I sent straightway to thee and gave commandment to his accusers also to say before thee what they had against him. Farewell.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the soldiers, as it was commanded them, took Paul and brought him by night to Antipatris.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day they left the horsemen to go with him and returned to the fortress,
speaker: Narrator

text: who, when they came to Caesarea and delivered the epistle to the governor, presented Paul also before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the governor had read the letter, he asked of what province he was. And when he understood that he was of Cilicia,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will hear thee, said he, when thine accusers are also come. And he commanded him to be kept in Herod’s judgment hall.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after five days Ananias, the prince of the priests, descended with the elders and with a certain orator named Tertullus, who informed the governor against Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he was called forth, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying, Seeing that by thee we enjoy great peace and that very worthy deeds are done unto this nation by thy prudence,
speaker: Narrator

text: we accept it always and in all places, most noble Felix, with all thankfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Notwithstanding, that I be not further tedious unto thee, I pray thee that thou would hear us of thy clemency a few words.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we have found this man a pestilent fellow and a mover of sedition among all the Jews throughout the world and prince of the seditious sect of the Nazarenes,
speaker: Narrator

text: who also has gone about to profane the temple, whom we took and would have judged according to our law.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the tribunal Lysias came upon us, and with great violence took him away out of our hands,
speaker: Narrator

text: commanding his accusers to come unto thee; by examining of whom thou may take knowledge of all these things, of which we accuse him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Jews also assented, saying that these things were so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Paul, after the governor had beckoned unto him to speak, answered, Forasmuch as I know that thou hast been of many years a judge unto this nation, I do the more cheerfully answer for myself;
speaker: Narrator

text: because thou art able to understand that there have been but twelve days since I went up to Jerusalem to worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they neither found me in the temple disputing with any man, neither raising up the people, neither in the synagogues, nor in the city,
speaker: Narrator

text: neither can they prove the things of which they now accuse me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But this I confess unto thee, that after the way which they call a sect, so worship I the God of my fathers, believing all things which are written in the law and in the prophets,
speaker: Narrator

text: and have hope toward God, which they themselves also allow, that there shall be a resurrection of the dead, both of the just and unjust.
speaker: Narrator

text: And for this reason do I exercise myself to have always a conscience void of offense toward God and toward men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now after many years I came to bring alms to my nation and offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whereupon certain Jews from Asia found me purified in the temple, neither with multitude, nor with tumult,
speaker: Narrator

text: who ought to have been here before thee and object if they had anything against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or else let these same here say if they have found any evil doing in me, while I stood before the council,
speaker: Narrator

text: except it be for this one voice, that I cried out standing among them, Touching the resurrection of the dead, I am called in question by you this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when Felix heard these things, he deferred them, saying, I shall have more information regarding that way, when Lysias the tribunal shall come down, Then I will know the uttermost of your matter.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he commanded a centurion to keep Paul and to let him have liberty, and that he should forbid none of his own to minister or come unto him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after certain days when Felix came with his wife Drusilla, who was a Jewess, he sent for Paul and heard of him the faith which is in Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as he reasoned of righteousness, temperance, and judgment to come, Felix trembled and answered, Go away for this time; when I have a convenient season, I will call for thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hoped also that money should have been given him from Paul, that he might loose him; therefore he sent for him many times and communed with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But after two years Felix received Porcius Festus as successor; and Felix, wanting to win the grace of the Jews, left Paul bound.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Festus was come into the province, after three days he ascended from Caesarea to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prince of the priests and the principals of the Jews informed him against Paul and besought him,
speaker: Narrator

text: asking for grace against him, that he would send for him to Jerusalem, they placing an ambush in the way to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Festus answered that Paul should be kept at Caesarea and that he himself would depart shortly there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them, therefore, said he, who among you are able, go down with me and accuse this man, if there is anything in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he had tarried among them no more than ten days, he went down unto Caesarea and the next day, sitting on the judgment seat, commanded Paul to be brought.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he was come, the Jews who came down from Jerusalem stood round about and laid many and grievous complaints against Paul, which they could not prove.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he answered for himself, Neither against the law of the Jews, neither against the temple, nor yet against Caesar have I sinned in anything at all.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Festus, willing to ingratiate himself with the Jews, answered Paul and said, Wilt thou go up to Jerusalem, and there be judged of these things before me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then said Paul, I stand at Caesar’s judgment seat, where I ought to be judged; to the Jews I have done no wrong, as thou very well knowest.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if I am an offender or have committed anything worthy of death, I do not refuse to die; but if there are none of these things of which these accuse me, no one may deliver me unto them. I appeal unto Caesar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Festus, when he had conferred with the council, answered, Hast thou appealed unto Caesar? unto Caesar shalt thou go.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after certain days King Agrippa and Bernice came unto Caesarea to salute Festus.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they had been there many days, Festus declared Paul’s cause unto the king, saying, There is a certain man left in bonds by Felix,
speaker: Narrator

text: about whom, when I was at Jerusalem, the princes of the priests and the elders of the Jews informed me, desiring to have vengeance against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: To whom I answered, It is not the manner of the Romans to deliver any man to die, before the one who is accused is face to face with his accusers and is given license to answer for himself concerning the crime laid against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, when they were come here, without any delay on the next day I sat on the judgment seat and commanded the man to be brought forth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Against whom when the accusers stood up, they brought no accusation of such things as I supposed,
speaker: Narrator

text: but had certain questions against him of their own superstition, and of one Jesus, who was dead, whom Paul affirmed to be alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because I doubted of such manner of questions, I asked him whether he would go to Jerusalem and there be judged of these matters.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Paul had appealed to be reserved unto the hearing of Augustus, I commanded him to be kept until I might send him to Caesar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Agrippa said unto Festus, I would also hear the man myself. Tomorrow, said he, thou shalt hear him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the next day when Agrippa was come and Bernice, with great pomp, and was entered into the place of hearing, with the tribunals and principal men of the city, at Festus’ commandment, Paul was brought forth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Festus said, King Agrippa, and all men who are here present with us, ye see this man, about whom all the multitude of the Jews have dealt with me, both at Jerusalem and also here, crying that he ought not to live any longer.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when I found that he had committed nothing worthy of death and that he himself has appealed to Augustus, I have determined to send him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of whom I have no certain thing to write unto my lord. Therefore I have brought him forth before you, and specially before thee, O King Agrippa, that, after examination, I might have something to write.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it seems to me unreasonable to send a prisoner, and not to signify the crimes laid against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Thou art permitted to speak for thyself. Then Paul stretched forth the hand and answered for himself:
speaker: Narrator

text: I esteem myself blessed, King Agrippa, because I shall answer for myself this day before thee concerning all the things of which I am accused of the Jews,
speaker: Narrator

text: especially because I know thee to be expert in all customs and questions which are among the Jews; therefore, I beseech thee to hear me patiently.
speaker: Narrator

text: My manner of life from my youth, which from the beginning was among my own nation at Jerusalem, is known of all the Jews,
speaker: Narrator

text: who knew me from the beginning, if they would testify, that after the most perfect sect of our religion I lived a Pharisee.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now I stand and am judged for the hope of the promise made of God unto our fathers;
speaker: Narrator

text: unto which promise our twelve tribes, constantly serving God day and night, hope to come. For which hope’s sake, King Agrippa, I am accused of the Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why should it be thought a thing incredible with you that God should raise the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: I verily had thought that I ought to do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Which things I also did in Jerusalem, and I shut up many of the saints in prison, having received authority from the princes of the priests, and when they were put to death, I gave my voice against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I punished them often in every synagogue and compelled them to blaspheme; and being exceedingly mad against them, I persecuted them even unto foreign cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whereupon as I went to Damascus with authority and commission from the princes of the priests,
speaker: Narrator

text: at midday, O king, I saw in the way a light from heaven, above the brightness of the sun, shining round about me and those who journeyed with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we were all fallen to the earth, I heard a voice speaking unto me and saying in the Hebrew tongue, Saul, Saul, why dost thou persecute me? It is hard for thee to kick against the pricks.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said, Who art thou, Lord? And he said, I am Jesus whom thou dost persecute.
speaker: Narrator

text: But rise and stand upon thy feet, for I have appeared unto thee for this purpose, to make thee a minister and a witness both of these things which thou hast seen and of those things in which I will appear unto thee;
speaker: Narrator

text: delivering thee from the people and from the Gentiles, unto whom now I send thee
speaker: Narrator

text: to open their eyes and to turn them from darkness to light and from the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive remission of sins and inheritance among those who are sanctified by the faith that is in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whereupon, O King Agrippa, I was not disobedient unto the heavenly vision,
speaker: Narrator

text: but I announced first unto those of Damascus and at Jerusalem and throughout all the coasts of Judaea and then to the Gentiles that they should repent and turn to God, doing works worthy of repentance.
speaker: Narrator

text: For these causes the Jews caught me in the temple and went about to kill me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Having, therefore, obtained help of God, I continue unto this day, witnessing both to small and great, saying no other things than those which the prophets and Moses said should come:
speaker: Narrator

text: that the Christ should suffer and that he should be the first that should rise from the dead and should show light unto this people and to the Gentiles.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as he spoke these things and answered for himself, Festus said with a loud voice, Paul, thou art beside thyself; much learning doth make thee mad.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, I am not mad, most noble Festus, but speak forth words of truth and temperance.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the king knows of these things, before whom I also speak freely; for I am persuaded that none of these things are hidden from him, for this thing was not done in a corner.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Agrippa, dost thou believe the prophets? I know that thou believest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Paul said, I desire before God that by little or by much, not only thou, but also all that hear me this day, were such as I am, except these bonds.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he had said these things, the king rose up and the governor and Bernice and those that sat with them;
speaker: Narrator

text: and when they were gone aside, they talked between themselves, saying, This man does nothing worthy of death or of bonds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Agrippa said unto Festus, This man might have been set at liberty if he had not appealed unto Caesar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when it was determined that we should sail unto Italy, they delivered Paul and certain other prisoners unto one named Julius, a centurion of the Augustus company.
speaker: Narrator

text: And entering into the ship, Adramyttium, we launched, meaning to sail by the coasts of Asia, one Aristarchus, a Macedonian of Thessalonica, being with us.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the next day we touched at Sidon. And Julius courteously entreated Paul and gave him liberty to go unto his friends to refresh himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we had launched from there, we sailed under Cyprus because the winds were contrary.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we had sailed over the sea of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra, a city of Lycia.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there the centurion found a ship of Alexandria sailing into Italy, and he put us in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we had sailed slowly many days and scarce were come over against Cnidus, the wind not allowing us, we sailed under Crete, over against Salmone,
speaker: Narrator

text: and, passing it with difficulty, came unto a place which is called The Fair Havens, near which was the city of Lasea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when much time was spent, and when sailing was now dangerous, because the fast was now already past, Paul admonished them,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, Sirs, I perceive that this voyage will be with hurt and much damage, not only of the lading and ship, but also of our lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless the centurion believed the master and the owner of the ship more than those things which were spoken by Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because the haven was not commodious to winter in, many were in agreement to depart from there also, if by any means they might attain to Phenice and winter there, which is a port of Crete and lies toward Africa and the west.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the south wind blew softly, supposing that they had obtained their purpose, raising sails, they sailed close by Crete.
speaker: Narrator

text: But not long after, there arose against it a tempestuous wind, called Euroclydon. {devastating cold north wind from Europe}
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the ship was caught up by it and could not resist against the wind, the ship was taken by the wind and drifted.
speaker: Narrator

text: And running under a certain island which is called Clauda, we had much work to come by the boat,
speaker: Narrator

text: Which when they had taken up, they used helps, undergirding the ship; and, fearing lest they should fall into Syrtis, {or the sandbanks} struck sail and so were driven.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we being exceedingly tossed with a tempest, the next day they lightened the ship;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the third day with our own hands we cast off the dead works of the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when neither sun nor stars in many days appeared and no small tempest lay on us, all hope that we should be saved was then lost.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then after long abstinence, Paul stood forth in the midst of them and said, Sirs, ye should have hearkened unto me and not have loosed from Crete to have avoided this harm and loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now I exhort you to be of good cheer, for there shall be no loss of any person’s life among you, but only of the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the angel of God stood by me this night, whose I am and whom I serve,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, Fear not, Paul; thou must be brought before Caesar; and, behold, God has given thee all those that sail with thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, sirs, be of good cheer; for I believe God, that it shall be even as it was told me.
speaker: Narrator

text: However we must be cast upon a certain island.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the fourteenth night was come as we were driven up and down in the Adriatic sea, about midnight the shipmen deemed that they drew near to some country
speaker: Narrator

text: and sounded and found it twenty fathoms; and when they had gone a little further, they sounded again and found it fifteen fathoms.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then fearing lest we should fall upon rocks, they cast four anchors out of the stern and wished for the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as the shipmen were about to flee out of the ship, when they had let down the boat into the sea, under colour as though they would have cast anchors out of the foreship,
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers, Except these abide in the ship, ye cannot be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the soldiers cut off the ropes of the boat and let her fall off.
speaker: Narrator

text: And while the day was coming on, Paul besought them all to take food, saying, This day is the fourteenth day that ye have waited and continued fasting, having taken nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I pray you to take some food, for this is for your salvation and health, for there shall not one hair fall from the head of any of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he had thus spoken, he took bread and gave thanks to God in presence of them all; and when he had broken it, he began to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they were all of good cheer, and they also took some food.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we were in all, in the ship, two hundred and seventy-six souls.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship and cast out the grain into the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when it was day, they did not recognize the land, but they discovered a certain gulf with a shore, into which they decided, if it were possible, to thrust in the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they had taken up the anchors, they committed themselves unto the sea and loosed the rudder bands and hoisted up the mainsail to the wind and made toward shore.
speaker: Narrator

text: But falling into a place where two seas met, they ran the ship aground; and the forepart stuck fast and remained unmovable, but the hinder part was broken with the violence of the waves.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the soldiers’ counsel was to kill the prisoners, lest any of them should swim out and escape.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the centurion, desiring to save Paul, frustrated this counsel and commanded that those who could swim should cast themselves first into the sea and get to land;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the rest, some on boards and some on broken pieces of the ship. And so it came to pass that they were all saved by making it to land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they were escaped, then we knew that the island was called Melita. {or Malta}
speaker: Narrator

text: And the barbarous people showed us no little kindness; for they kindled a great fire and received all of us because of the present rain and because of the cold.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks and laid them on the fire, a viper came out of the heat and fastened on his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the barbarians saw the venomous beast hang on his hand, they said among themselves, No doubt this man is a murderer, whom, though he has escaped the sea, yet vengeance does not suffer him to live.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he shook off the beast into the fire and felt no harm.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they were waiting to see when he should have swollen or fallen down dead suddenly; but after they had waited a great while and saw no harm come to him, they changed their minds and said that he was a god.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same quarters were possessions of a principal man of the island, whose name was Publius, who received us and lodged us three days courteously.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it came to pass that the father of Publius lay sick of a fever and of dysentery, to whom Paul entered in and prayed and laid his hands on him and healed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when this was done, others also, who had diseases in the island, came and were healed,
speaker: Narrator

text: who also honoured us with many gifts; and when we departed, they laded us with such things as were necessary.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after three months we departed in a ship of Alexandria, which had wintered in the isle, whose ensign was Castor and Pollux.
speaker: Narrator

text: And landing at Syracuse, we tarried there three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: And having gone around, we came to Rhegium, and after one day the south wind blew, and we came the next day to Puteoli,
speaker: Narrator

text: where we found brethren, who asked us to tarry with them seven days, and so we went toward Rome.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from there, when the brethren heard of us, they came to meet us as far as Appii Forum and The Three Taverns whom when Paul saw, he thanked God and took courage.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we came to Rome, the centurion delivered the prisoners to the praetorian prefect, but Paul was allowed to dwell by himself with a soldier that kept him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it came to pass, that after three days Paul called the principals of the Jews together, and when they were come together, he said unto them, Men and brethren, though I have committed nothing against the people or customs of our fathers, yet was I delivered prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans,
speaker: Narrator

text: who, when they had examined me, would have let me go because there was no cause of death in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the Jews spoke against it, I was constrained to appeal unto Caesar, not that I had anything to accuse my nation of.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this cause therefore I have called for you, to see you and to speak with you: because for the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said unto him, We neither received letters out of Judaea concerning thee, neither any of the brethren that came showed or spoke any harm of thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we desire to hear of thee what thou thinkest; for as concerning this sect, we know that everywhere it is spoken against.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they had appointed him a day, many came to him into his lodging, to whom he expounded and testified the kingdom of God, procuring to persuade them of that concerning Jesus, the Christ, out of the law of Moses and out of the prophets, from morning until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: And some believed the things which were spoken, and some did not believe.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they did not agree among themselves, they departed, after Paul had spoken this word, Well spoke the Holy Spirit by Isaiah the prophet unto our fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, Go unto this people, and say, Hearing ye shall hear and shall not understand; and seeing ye shall see and not perceive;
speaker: Narrator

text: for the heart of this people is waxed gross, and their ears are dull of hearing, and their eyes have they closed; lest they should see with their eyes and hear with their ears and understand with their heart and should be converted and I should heal them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be it known, therefore, unto you that this saving health of God is sent unto the Gentiles and that they will hear it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he had said these words, the Jews departed and had a great dispute among themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Paul dwelt two whole years in his own hired house and received all that came in unto him,
speaker: Narrator

text: preaching the kingdom of God and teaching those things which concern the Lord Jesus Christ, with all liberty, without hindrance.
speaker: Narrator
